Then overwrite with your own code files.

issue.title: Simple, single robot submission Docker file

content.raw: Is sending the whole development environment in Solution Container a guiding idea here? I’m still trying to figure out why do I need 3.9GB image in order to send my 6.1MB executable.

issue.title: Simple, single robot submission Docker file

content.raw:
Once you’ve uploaded the docker image the first time, subsequent uploads only upload the layers that have changed.

To speed up building the image locally, I just rsync my local code and `subt` repo copies into the build context \(leaving out the `.hg` and `.git` directories, which are pretty huge

‌
content.html:
Once you’ve uploaded the docker image the first time, subsequent uploads only upload the layers that have changed.

To speed up building the image locally, I just rsync my local code and subt repo copies into the build context (leaving out the .hg and .git directories, which are pretty huge

‌

issue.title: Simple, single robot submission Docker file

content.raw:
Paul - that’s what we tried for the tunnel circuit final, building the docker from the local catkin workspace. We didn’t have enough time to test and make it work and eventually our program didn’t work when they ran it.

That’s why our first task for the urban circuit was to make sure our Docker submission works, and for that we started with their sample solution docker, after which we copied our code and installed required libraries. Not being very experienced with Docker, this was much easier.
content.html:
Paul - that’s what we tried for the tunnel circuit final, building the docker from the local catkin workspace. We didn’t have enough time to test and make it work and eventually our program didn’t work when they ran it.

That’s why our first task for the urban circuit was to make sure our Docker submission works, and for that we started with their sample solution docker, after which we copied our code and installed required libraries. Not being very experienced with Docker, this was much easier.

issue.title: Simple, single robot submission Docker file

content.raw:
You at least need the ability to interface with ROS on your Solution Container.  Your solution container can be a small as you want it to be, the easiest way to do it though is to just extend off of the `subt` workspace docker and upload your docker image.  Future docker image regeneration can be much faster since you're just modifying a few layers you're putting on top of the extended `subt` workspace docker and only the layers with changes will need to be uploaded.

I believe the `subt_seed` example has a docker image build and I know `subt_helloworld` has proposed workflow docker container development and docker container submission.
content.html:
You at least need the ability to interface with ROS on your Solution Container. Your solution container can be a small as you want it to be, the easiest way to do it though is to just extend off of the subt workspace docker and upload your docker image. Future docker image regeneration can be much faster since you're just modifying a few layers you're putting on top of the extended subt workspace docker and only the layers with changes will need to be uploaded.

I believe the subt_seed example has a docker image build and I know subt_helloworld has proposed workflow docker container development and docker container submission.
